description.text: RNA Secondary Structure Prediction and Comparison.

doc.title: RNAsubopt

description.text: Calculate suboptimal secondary structures of RNAs

doc.reference: S. Wuchty, W. Fontana, I. L. Hofacker and P. Schuster Complete Suboptimal Folding of RNA and the Stability of Secondary Structures, Biopolymers, 49, 145-165 (1999)

comment.text: RNAsubopt reads RNA sequences from file and (in the default -e mode) calculates all suboptimal secondary structures within a user defined energy range above the minimum free energy (mfe).It prints the suboptimal structures in bracket notation followed by the energy in kcal/mol to stdout. Be careful, the number of structures returned grows exponentially with both sequence length and energy range.
Alternatively, when used with the -p option, RNAsubopt produces Boltzmann weighted samples of secondary structures.

xhtml:div.label: Calculate suboptimal structures within this range kcal/mol of the mfe (-e)
Rescale energy parameters to a temperature of temperature Celcius (-T)
Do not include special stabilizing energies for certain tetraloops (-4) Yes No

How to treat dangling end energies for bases adjacent to helices in free ends and multiloops (-d)?
Only unpaired bases can participate in at most one dangling end (-d1) Ignores dangling ends altogether (-d0) The check is ignored (-d2) Coaxial stacking of adjacent helices in multi-loops (-d3)
Change treatment of dangling ends, as in RNAfold and RNAeval. The default is -d2 (as in partition function folding). If -d1 or -d3 are specified the structures are generated as with -d2 but energies are re-evaluated before printing.

Recalculate energies of structures using a logarithmic energy function for multi-loops (-logML)?
Yes No
This option does not effect structure generation, only the energies that is printed out. Since logML lowers energies somewhat, some structures may be missing.

Only print structures with energy within this prange of the mfe (-ep)?
Only print structures with energy within prange of the mfe. Useful in conjunction with -logML, -d1 or -d3: while the -e option specifies the range before energies are re-evaluated, -ep specifies the maximum energy after re-evaluation.

Sort the structures by energy (-s)?
Yes No
Since the sort in is done in memory, this becomes impractical when the number of structures produced goes into millions.

Avoid lonely pairs (helices of length 1) (-noLP)?
Yes No
Only produce structures without lonely pairs (helices of length 1). This reduces the number of structures drastically and should therefore be used for longer sequences and larger energy ranges.
Do not allow GU pairs (-noGU) Yes No
Do not allow GU pairs at the end of helices (-noCloseGU) Yes No

Non standard pairs (comma seperated list) (-nsp)?
Allow other pairs in addition to the usual AU,GC,and GU pairs. pairs is a comma seperated list of additionally allowed pairs. If a the first character is a '-' then AB will imply that AB and BA are allowed pairs. e.g. RNAfold -nsp -GA will allow GA and AG pairs. Nonstandard pairs are given 0 stacking energy.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Read energy parameters from paramfile, instead of using the default parameter set. A sample parameterfile should accompany your distribution. See the RNAlib documentation for details on the file format.

xhtml:div.label: Calculate z score Yes No

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Change treatment of dangling ends, as in RNAfold and RNAeval. The default is -d2 (as in partition function folding). If -d1 or -d3 are specified the structures are generated as with -d2 but energies are re-evaluated before printing.
This option does not effect structure generation, only the energies that is printed out. Since logML lowers energies somewhat, some structures may be missing.

Only print structures with energy within prange of the mfe. Useful in conjunction with -logML, -d1 or -d3: while the -e option specifies the range before energies are re-evaluated, -ep specifies the maximum energy after re-evaluation.
Since the sort in is done in memory, this becomes impractical when the number of structures produced goes into millions.
Only produce structures without lonely pairs (helices of length 1). This reduces the number of structures drastically and should therefore be used for longer sequences and larger energy ranges.

Allow other pairs in addition to the usual AU,GC,and GU pairs. pairs is a comma seperated list of additionally allowed pairs. If a the first character is a '-' then AB will imply that AB and BA are allowed pairs. e.g. RNAfold -nsp -GA will allow GA and AG pairs. Nonstandard pairs are given 0 stacking energy.

Read energy parameters from paramfile, instead of using the default parameter set. A sample parameterfile should accompany your distribution. See the RNAlib documentation for details on the file format.

parameter.name: mfe
parameter.prompt: Calculate suboptimal structures within this range kcal/mol of the mfe (-e)

format.code: ("", " -e " + str(value))[value is not None and value != vdef]

interface.label: Calculate suboptimal structures within this range kcal/mol of the mfe (-e)

parameter.name: temperature
parameter.prompt: Rescale energy parameters to a temperature of temperature Celcius (-T)

format.code: ( "" , " -T " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

interface.label: Rescale energy parameters to a temperature of temperature Celcius (-T)

parameter.name: tetraloops
parameter.prompt: Do not include special stabilizing energies for certain tetraloops (-4)

interface.label: Do not include special stabilizing energies for certain tetraloops (-4) Yes No

parameter.name: dangling
parameter.prompt: How to treat dangling end energies for bases adjacent to helices in free ends and multiloops (-d)

Coaxial stacking of adjacent helices in multi-loops (-d3)

format.code: "/local/gensoft/libexec/ViennaRNA/readseq -f=19 -a "+ str(seq) + " > "+ str(seq) +".tmp && (cp "+ str(seq) +" "+ str(seq) +".orig && mv "+ str(seq) +".tmp "+ str(seq) +") ; "
